oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Driving to the Applachian Exposition at Chilhowee Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Claiming Space
Leisure
African American women; African Americans; Automobiles
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Open car driven by a chauffeur with four well-dressed women and a girl holding an American flag. "Mitchell 5624" on automobile radiator grill.

Historian Robert J. Booker has identified several of those in the open car on its way to the first Appalachian Exposition, which was held at Knoxville's Chilhowee Park in 1910, as follows: the young lady, front seat right, with parasol, (Mrs.) Bessie Settle (Richardson) and the young girl in the center as (Mrs.) Margaret Singleton (Carson). See Robert J. Booker, Two Hundred Years of Black Culture in Knoxville, Tennessee, 1791-1991 (Virginia Beach, VA : Donning Co., 1993), 90.
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Two Hundred Years of Black Culture in Knoxville, Tennessee, 1791-1991, by Robert J. Booker
